page.title: 12FARMING,HUSBANDRY OF CNEWR
page.content: By the end of the nineteenth century the size of the Cnewr Company flocks had increased to avout 14,000 head of sheep. Now it is somewhat smaller. For example, there were about 11,000 breeding ewes in the nineteen thirties which, by 1980, had declined to 5,200. The NEATH AND BRECON RAILWAY, the form -er track of which passes through the middle of the estate, was completed about 10 years after McTurk came to Cnewr. This provided an important transport link from the station at Crai, which is only a mile or so from Cnewr, to move animals and wool for sale and slaughter. At that time the wool crop used to be sent by rail to Scotland, where better prices obtain- ed. Moreover Robert McTurk also obtain -ed a lease on land at Llywncyntefin near Sennybridge giving easy access to the annual sheep sale still held there
